thread.title: Celebrate Nottingham's favourite outlaw, stop by the eccentric October Plenty festival and marvel at York's beautiful architecture: Autumn events to delight the entire family
thread.title_full: Celebrate Nottingham's favourite outlaw, stop by the eccentric October Plenty festival and marvel at York's beautiful architecture: Autumn events to delight the entire family | Daily Mail Online

author: Katie Rowe For The Mail On Sunday
title: Celebrate Nottingham's favourite outlaw, stop by the eccentric October Plenty festival and marvel at York's beautiful architecture: Autumn events to delight the entire family
text:
17 shares 1
View
comments
Looking to keep the entire family entertained this October?
Whether you prefer a quirky carnival or a circus festival, there's a whole host of events to choose from - with many located just outside your doorstep.
Here, we've selected some of the best to inspire an enjoyable day (or evening) out this autumn.
For a fun family autumn outing, head to the Illuminating York festival when the city's historic architecture is transformed in modern works of art
Robin Hood Beer and Cider Festival
Choose from more than 1,100 different real ales, not to mention over 300 real ciders and perries at Nottingham’s annual CAMRA festival between October 7 and 10.
Held in the magnificent grounds of Nottingham Castle, this is a beer festival to top them all, with the widest choice of draught cask conditioned beers in the world.
October also sees Nottingham celebrate its famous outlaw, with a series of events and performances kicking off with International Robin Hood Day on October 17, followed by the Robin Hood Pageant in the grounds of Nottingham Castle from October 23 to 25.
Boscastle Food, Art AND Craft Festival
Sumptuous food, top-notch producers and appearances by Michelin-starred chefs are just some of the tasty highlights of this coastal festival celebrating the best of Cornish cuisine and crafts.
 Next Walk in the footsteps of Queen Victoria or visit King... Private pools, some of the world's finest snorkelling and... Travelling in style... sort of: Passenger is collected on... Family speaks of shock after arriving at Airbnb villa in... 17 shares Get a flavour of what life is like in the kitchen as Cornwall’s leading local talent show off their skills and reveal top tips, or try local honey as you swot up on beekeeping before browsing beautifully made artworks, jewellery and pottery – all with a Cornish twist.
The fun takes place between October 3 and 4.
October Plenty
Kicking off on London’s Bankside beside Shakespeare’s Globe on October 25, this eccentric carnival is everything you wished your school’s harvest festival could have been.
A celebration of Southwark’s plentiful history, ancient seasonal customs and theatrical performance all rolled into one, the Berry Man – festooned head-to-toe in wild fruits and foliage – is the star of the show, along with the annual Apple Day event held at the famous Borough Market.
Another family-friendly festival is October Plenty, with its annual Apple Day held at Borough Market in London
Circus City
Bristol’s biennial circus festival, which this year runs from October 8 to 31, attracts top local talent and award-winning European shows, dazzling audiences with everything from spellbinding cabaret to puppetry.
Take your seat for nail-biting wire-walking shows and bring out your inner clown or trapeze artist with masterclasses and workshops for all skill levels and ages.
Family Fright Nights at Abbotsbury Subtropical Gardens
Big and little kids alike are invited to don spooky fancy dress for a series of Halloween Fright Nights at one of Dorset’s most idyllic gardens between October 29 and 31.
Join a spectacular laser rave, a scary scars workshop and a creepy-crawly bug show. All events take place in the magical glow of the garden’s Enchanted Illuminations, with trees and plants casting eerie shadows from every angle.
Illuminating York
As the nights draw in, York’s historic architecture is transformed into modern works of art. Medieval landmarks become the canvas for striking art installations, lighting up the dark nights with swathes of colour.
Drawing more than 50,000 visitors to the city from October 28 to 30, the event sees the majestic facade of York Minster drenched in a kaleidoscope of colour, The Shambles will go all disco with mirror balls suspended above the medieval shopping street, and the Museum Gardens will be transformed by a barrage of light and sound.
For more holiday ideas, see visitengland.com .
